commentBody: Easy Friday!!
Isnt 'diffrent " spelled Different ( strokes ) ?
Calling it cheesepie would be insanity
Pretty straightforward but the clue for 38D was gold.
Easy for a Friday, but I'll take it.
Constitutional in my house has an entirely different meaning, and it usually involves a coffee and a newspaper.

I enjoyed your puzzle, Mr Clinchy, thank you.


Perchance was your father a high school teacher in Westchester County, NY in the 1980s and '90s?
16D was a delightful gimme for me.  PAOLO is a relative of mine!
Sitting next to our dog and saying "Wok! Walk! EnTREATies!" made us suspicious that he played a role in creating this puzzle...

Just came by to say, with the strike and all, I'm leaving for a while.

Be well, friends, good friends, and Barry.

How is this a Friday puzzle?  I kept looking up to check the date again and again.  It first seemed like a Monday, maybe a Tuesday.  The center left gave me a little pause but the whole thing went very quickly and there wasn't a whole lot of wordplay involved.  Diff'rent Strokes was particularly disappointing.  Just a straight up question and answer.  At least the other "spanner" tried.

We've had 3 stellar theme puzzles this same week.  I found today's themeless disappointing.  It would have been fine for a Wednesday maybe?

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

I liked this puzzle a lot. Just the right crunch - finished a bit below Friday average. 

There‚Äôs a difference (er‚Ä¶ diff‚Äôrence?) between ‚Äúeasy for a Friday‚Äù and ‚Äútoo easy for a Friday‚Äù. In my opinion this puzzle is definitely the former, which is just fine by me once in a while.

Great job, Evans Clinchy!
Am I the only one who is tired of using bread as a stand in for money?

I enjoyed this puzzle quite a bit. I did find the French bread to be a pretty big stretch. Even European bread would've been less deliberately deceptive. Or even "new French bread" just anything to give a hint it was an unusual clue. If I had known Audi I would've probably gotten there though..

Stumbled a bit in the lower left corner but still finished 25% faster than average for a Friday‚Ä¶ 

Well of a Friday PB so I guess it wasn‚Äôt a Monday difficulty as some are alleging‚Ä¶
I wanted nickel/dime to be Twain, but I realize a nickel might actually have been worth a dime back then.

Repost from yesterday 

Supporting the strike. Not playing

I really made this one hard for myself by misremembering the quote as "... an obvious fake". Made the whole northwest corner much more of a headscratcher than it needed to be!

I do love the clueing of ELLIOT PAGE with reference to the Umbrella Academy. That show was probably the best project he could have been involved with at such a crucial moment in his life.

This one only took about half my Friday average (though it wasn‚Äôt my fastest solve ever), but it was pretty fun. I had a bit of a snag with 57A, as I kept thinking of the famous John Donne poem line (which would seem to definitively make ISLE *not* the answer), and I thought the Crown Dependency was spelled ‚ÄúMann‚Äù; apparently‚Äîlooking it up post-solve‚Äîboth spellings are in use.
The "parent company of Bentley" clue is wrong, as its answer also is under a single parent company that is the correct answer. Hint: they're "the people's car".
Flew right through this one. Good stuff.
Some say ‚Äúeasy,‚Äù some say ‚Äúhard.‚Äù   Not easy for me (51 minutes) but I managed a gold star.  I don‚Äôt know how some of you just race through these puzzles. :-)
A Friday PB for me!  On its wavelength for sure, with some cute clues.  No whining, no complaining...

"  My original clue for 15-Across was, [He wrote in his 2023 memoir, ‚ÄúThe movement for trans liberation affects us all‚Äù].   Poignant words, especially at times like these."

Poignant words that got rejected for a clue and replaced with a basic imdb reference.Too bad !
I finished one of Mr. Clinchy‚Äôs more interesting puzzles (March 4, 2016) last week. It‚Äôs difficult, but doable. If you enjoyed this one, it‚Äôs a good follow up.

I would like to introduce a superstition/folkway into our collective crossword culture: When in the course of beginning a puzzle, you say to yourself "Oh, this one is going to be easy" the answers will immediately dry up. Never do that! Wait until the end to decide whether or not it's easy or hard!
First time through I confidently entered "gear" for "word before or after head."  All four letters wrong, but I eventually got it.  I liked the right answer even better.
In light of recent events, perhaps 40D could have been clued, ‚ÄúOne who might stay home when they are blue?‚Äù
Constitutional has a DIFFRENT meaning these days.
Any recommendations for alternative puzzles to do while the strike is going on? Missing my crossword fix..

Strands #250

Wanted to start this thread early because I have a question that can't be discussed without spoiling today's puzzle.  

And I guess I'm outing myself as crossing the digital picket line but took the advice offered here earlier that not playing  Strands/Connections et. al. will have zero impact.
A very satisfying puzzle! I especially enjoyed the Arthur Conan Doyle quote. It‚Äôs very apt in today‚Äôs climate.

For a brief moment this morning I thought it was Tuesday, and the last few days were just a bad dream. Then I realized it really was Friday and I was a victim of wishful thinking. Oh well, nice puzzle anyhow.

Despite some mildly misleading clues, and a little bit of a slow down in the lower third, I finished this one in reasonable time.  I fell right into the pain (rather than EURO) trap for French bread and briefly puzzled over ‚ÄúMan for one‚Äù before coming up with ISLE. and, although not misleading per se,  I tried Ralph before PIGGY.  

The Lord Of The Flies reference brought back memories of junior high and high school where LOTF was featured in 3 different (not DIFFRENT) English classes, which I thought showed a lack of imagination on the part of the English department.  My father, a college professor and former high school principal, went to parent teacher
 night the third time it showed up on my reading list, and accosted the teacher who had assigned it.  In consequence, those in the class who were bored of the Flies, were instead allowed to read On The Beach, a similarly apocalyptic story.  The unintended consequence of my father‚Äôs action was that I got the lowest grade in that class that I received in my high school career, retribution from the assuredly irritated teacher.

Seeing GIL Scott-Heron cheered me up a bit.  I was reminded that:  ‚ÄúThe revolution will not be televised. It will not be brought to you by Xerox in four parts without commercial interruptions.‚Äù And thinking of his other most famous piece, which I won‚Äôt name here for fear of running afoul of the emus, put me in mind of how to contextualize those who are obsessed with colonizing Mars.
I predict an uptick in REI's business.  Spending more time outdoors is healing.  It's better than a CHEESECAKE BINGE washed down with CRAFT BEERS.

I feel bad about crossing a digital picket line, but I so badly need puzzle therapy right now that I can‚Äôt even conceive of stepping away. I‚Äôve done so many (archive) crosswords in the last few days that I can‚Äôt even keep count. I crave the sense of logic, reason, and creativity they provide, and when so much in the world makes no sense, at least I know I can find some here. So while  I deeply apologize to the staffers I am offending by my presence here, I hope you can find it in your hearts to forgive me.

I enjoyed this puzzle, even if my own stubbornness kept me from solving it more quickly than I should have. I was sure that the answer to ‚ÄúFrench bread‚Äù should be ‚Äúpain‚Äù, and likewise held on to ‚Äúpeers at‚Äù instead of PERUSES for far too long. But I got there, and without any lookups. So maybe the puzzles are also teaching me about open-mindedness. That‚Äôs something I will really need to embrace in the months ahead.

Btw, in Polish we call cheesecake "sernik", which basically translates as "cheesy thing". Yet it most definitely is considered a cake. Nobody would ever call one a pie (placek). Perhaps this is due to the fact that traditionally Polish sernik always contained flour and was always baked (and as a result rather dry). Some imported cheesecake styles are indeed tarts, but would never be called that. Interesting interaction between language and globalization, this.

Again!

This week my son decided to make
his TRES LECHES cake.

He insists on making it entirely from scratch,
and doesn‚Äôt have all the equipment,
so he comes over, 
three (tres) days in a row to use our kitchen.

We not only get the most delicious treat,
but three days of chats with our boy!

He‚Äôll finish it today, but as I solved,
I thought about that sweet masterpiece 
sitting in my fridge.

And then,
there it was.

A sign I could take a *little* bite for breakfast..?

I can‚Äôt think of any other reasonable explanation.

Very nice Friday.
Thank you Evans!

Always fun to see a Yogi Berra quote.  One of the best gifts I ever got my dad was a book of Yogi-isms, which I think was called When You Come to a Fork in the Road, Take It, which is also one of my favorite Yogi sayings.

Two 15 letter answers and six 10 letter answers, and of all of those, only... CHEESECAKE ever appeared in another Shortz era puzzle and only ENTREATIES even appeared in a pre-Shortz puzzle. All the others were debuts. But... only TRESLECHES was completely unfamiliar to me.  

That's pretty impressive, but also made for a heck of a challenge for me and I had to cheat some to get through this one. That's all on me. 

Unusual puzzle find today - a Tuesday from January 26, 2016 by Sam Ezersky. The 'reveal' referenced two clues: 

35a -"With 43-Across, singer of the lyric formed by the first parts of 20-, 24-, 40-, 51- and 58-Across :" 
DAVID
and 43a was: 
BOWIE 

And then those 5 referenced answers:

20a - GROUNDOUTS
24a - CONTROLFREAK
40a - TOTASTE
51a - MAJORPROBLEM
58a - TOMFOOLERY

Don't recall seeing anything like that before. Just amazing. 

I'll shut up now. 

..

O NYT XW, must you keep reminding me about work?

In *the Baker's Manual* (fifth edition, 2002), pastry chef Joe Amendola discusses cheesecake under the chapter on custards, and I tend to agree: desserts or dessert components in which the primary binding is gently cooked eggs. Along with pots de cr√®me, lemon curd, and cr√®me anglaise, etc.

In that work, Mr. Amendola doesn't mention tres leches at all.

*The Baker's Manual* is one of the few cookbooks I would actually recommend, for professional or home use.

***

Well, I guess I've crossed the digital picket line. 
If I may opine all curmudgeonly for a minute, one of the strikers' demands bothers me as egregious overreach--and I'm not talking about "pet bereavement." I have little sympathy with employees who demand that they be able to "work from home," and complain when they are required to be present bodily in the office. (And better quit now, lest I say something that many would take as truly insensitive.)
 
But of course, "work from home" has never been an option for me: it's rather difficult to fax a cheesecake or tres leches into the hotel from home. 

And FWIW, I *have* stood on a picket line, for a month in late fall. One of the hardest things I've ever done, even harder that work, but one which, should the situation demand, I'd do again. Luckily, we recently signed a new contract.

So a stupidly broken streak--now back to finish Tues.-Thurs.; did I miss much? But I did discover that the WSJ puzzle is quite good.

This puzzle gave me a lovely mix of work and play.

The play came in the form of several splat-fills ‚Äì bam bam bams ‚Äì which always feel like a thrilling sled ride.  The work came from answers out of my everyday rotation (CULTRAL ATTACHE, TOMFOOLS), and answers totally out of my wheelhouse (ELLIOT PAGE and TRES LECHES).  I adore the labor involved in conquering the unfamiliar.

This is a beautifully designed grid ‚Äì never seen in the Times before ‚Äì with lots of flow, that is, no almost-fully-detached islands.  It accommodates a generous 14 long answers (eight letters or more), and the longs today, IMO, overall have zing.

Speaking of zing, there are eight NYT answer debuts.  One of them ‚Äì BIG BREAK ‚Äì I can‚Äôt believe has never appeared before in the 80+ years of the Times puzzle.

One more note: [Eyeball] for OGLE came off to me as a misdirect, because it‚Äôs so often clued in a way that refers to its creepy vibe.

Work and play in the same box, bringing the sweet gifts of satisfaction and ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù, well, that makes me a happy solver.  Thank you so much for this, Evans!

REI IRES me every time, only because it just won‚Äôt stick in my brain.

(Maybe now I‚Äôll remember it, since ‚ÄúRecreational Engrams Irk‚Äù)

A fairly Friday feel for me.
Breezy fun and personal best for a Friday. Thanks, Evan!
Oops -  just read about the strike. Sorry, tech workers. Stepping back away from the line. . .Heading over to WaPo with Bezos?Nah. Time for my favorite media giants to do the right thing(s).
What Big Joe Turner was to rock&roll, Gil Scott-Heron is to rap.

Sorry to say I just read all about the strike on Salon.  Everyone here should go have a look.  This will set a precedent for the tech industry.
We will have to go dark for a while; go back to copying the puzzles at our library for a while.

But today's puzzle was right up our alley, loved the cluing and all the alternative cultural references.  Made us smile.  A lot.

Thanks, Evans

ZEALOTRY indeed.  We got it done. 

However, we will be hiding in a corner for the next four years or watching the original Godzilla with crabcakes.

Thank you Evans, a really good puzzle.

Yeah, well, I got, and with no help. Took a hour. Really, I thought it was a hard rain's a gonna fall and not hail. A hard reign did in fact fall a few days ago. but it's like the man says: Don't take life too seriously; you'll never get out of it alive.
Hey, hey Boo-Boo. Which reminds me: half the things attributed to Yogi were uttered by him. Fun anyway. And profound in their own way.

Today I learned that Different Strokes is spelled DIFFRENT STROKES in TV land.  Another contemporary nail in the coffin of people learning/knowing how to spell correctly.  

OMG.  Considering the staggering cost of First Class, Business Class, or even a seat with extra legroom in Economy,  plus all the extra charges for luggage, I should worry about how "pricey" a CRAFT BEER is?  I might as well order two.

A lovely putdown of LAS VEGAS.  I saw it at the young, impressionable age of 16 and was thoroughly unimpressed.  I've never had the slightest desire to go back.

This was like two puzzles:  the section that had ELLIOT PAGE, GIL and PAOLO (whoever they all are) crossing each other and the sections that didn't.  Does anyone in editorial keep an eye on criss-crossing names anymore?  There is SO much of it now.  Every.  Single.  Day.  Because I solved the puzzle without looking any of them up, I suppose it means the puzzle was fairer than it seemed while I was solving it.  But once again my teeth were gritted.  As for the "friend of Scuttle, Flounder and Sebastian" -- what drivel.  But at least the answer sat in a corner of the puzzle far, far away from the rest of the PPP.

Best clues:  ABBOTS (got it immediately); FACT; CULTURAL ATTACHE and BERRA.  Berra's quotes are usually the high point of any puzzle.  Unfathomable clue for ZINGS.  I guess both "sick" and "burns" are being used in slang-y ways I don't really understand.

Surprisingly smooth given what the calendar says but still fun with [Big brothers?] the favorite. 

The history of the development of the craft brewery business here in NJ which was able to work around the limitations on liquor licenses to become, well, bars.  You can't turn the corner without coming across a new one.   Sorry but $8 for a pint is still too much no matter how crafty the brew.  And what's with these cloudy beers?

Also sprach the curmudgeon .

I had the high road up on a mountain RANGE.  That little tangle was the last to fall, after I gave up BACON (which I never put on pizza).
SIMON before PIGGY
IRKS before the unforgiveable IRES

23D ???ARIEL ??  "Flounder" made me think of "Animal House" so I was really far afield.  Still don't "get it."  ?Disney movie? Ick.

Okay, our son says the NYT administrators walked out Sunday and  assures me the angels are on the side of the Tech Folk.  I'll come back to Comments when this mess is cleared up.  Sigh.  I will send $$ to their fund to atone for being here...

Catch you on the other side of the Great Rift.
So nobody uses a wok for potstickers. You  know pot stickers are flat-bottomed right. Believe it or not, flat bottomed pans also exist in China
Captain Q, Thinking of you. https://www.newyorker.com/cartoon/a27619
This was a very quick Friday for me, even without knowing some of the proper nouns. I had fun - well....dare I say it?? Diff'rent Strokes.

Wow, it did not even occur to me that movie REELS were a thing of the past. Well, of course, it must all be digital now. I will miss that whirring, clicking sound emanating from the projection booth. Thanks for making me feel old, Mr Clinchy. (Other than that and the WOK clue, the puzzle was quite fine.)

Boy this one was "deceptive."

Entered a lot of wrong ones before gradually sussing it out. 

Shame on this charter Mets fan for not immediately entering Berra.

I get the "pricey" part, but if by "flight" the constructor means ordering an IPA on an airplane I think that's a stretch! Or maybe I just don't get the allusion?

Another "gentle" Friday puzzle. I've already spent more time trying to find the commonality among the purple group in today's Connections than I needed for the puzzle. (Please, no spoilers! I won't submit a group until/unless I figure out the connection.)

Nice grid, all in all, with some interesting long entries (TOMFOOLS, ZEALOTRY) and very little dreck.
For those of us who seldom conquer the Friday puzzle, the ever-present question: was this puzzle easy or was I good?
So, if a word (Diff'rent) has an apostrophe in it, should the apostrophe not be part of the spelling and have its own square?
Thanks a lot! Now, I must go to the nearest Fiesta and grab a big TRES LECHES... Yummy.
Devil's Backbone 8 Point IPA floated my boat In Nellysford, VA. The rugged Blue Ridge Mountains were called the "Devil's Backbone" by Peter Jefferson father of Thomas Jefferson.
I didn‚Äôt hear about the strike until last night. I have signed out of the NYT Games and Cooking apps and will stop playing. I‚Äôm giving up my streaks in support of the NYT Tech Guild. Solidarity.

Fair but tough one, had to resort to the hints so as not to take up my entire friday morning. My nits, PERUSES seems like a casual read rather than a close read. And I believe Bentley is owned by VW, which also owns AUDI and a million other brands.
My best performance on a Friday puzzle! Of course I had a little help but I'm pleased!  Thank you
First Friday I've completed without any help - no hints, no Google, nada! Yay!
Did anyone else put IRKS for "33A Makes angry" instead of IRES ?  That cost me some time, and I question the use of the latter.
Hi!  I need some help. I got the whole puzzle but I didn't understand what "two" had to do with "cutesy." (got it because the c was the only option).

In the early nineties I worked for a government agency represented by a white collar union. I was elected to represent our bargaining unit in contract negotiations twice. To me, it was never a matter of union: good/management: bad. We were representing the interests of different parties. Our side was fighting tooth and nail to maintain benefits that, even then, almost no one in the private sector enjoyed: retirement after 20 years of service and free health, vision and dental insurance for life for ourselves and families. Management was adamant that the cost was unsustainable without tax increases, which was a dealbreaker from their perspective.

When I first learned about the dispute I read what I could find with the idea that I would suspend my account for the duration. But based on what I found, I can‚Äôt say that I understand enough to form an opinion. Frankly, if one doesn‚Äôt have a seat at the table, it‚Äôs pretty difficult to really understand what the stakes are.

I completely respect the decisions others have made to support the guild. I just don‚Äôt feel anyone should feel pressured to take a side without understanding the issues. I‚Äôve paid for my subscription and these games have gotten me through a lot over the past few years. That being said, if I can find more clear information I will reconsider.
I adored the New York Yankees since I was twelve years old. Imagine how I felt when I had Yogi‚Äôs grandson, Larry, in my U.S. history class! He was very well behaved.

The northwest corner was painful.  I had PAIN for french bread and I was certain that the end of pricey flight options was LEERS not to mention the apostrophe in DIFF'RENTSTROKES.  

Also, isn't VW the owner of Bentley.  I sussed out AUDI but really didn't love that cluing.

Solid puzzle though.
I want to say something snarky about the puzzle but I can't think of anything.  Any ideas?
fell asleep last night while solving this puzzle‚Äîwoke up this morning to finish it and it saved my streak üòÖ
Wasn't too difficult and got the gold star in under 10 minutes. Liked the misdirect at 14A
@Dave no - the show is titled Diff'rent Strokes
@Seth I dare you to try and explain why.

@Ace

Just the Facts of Life.
@MikeW agree about the (lack of) difficulty and the clue. 49D was my favourite. I don't know if it's a novel clue, but I can't remember seeing it before and thought it was clever.

@Alex 

Really?  49D seemed so flat and pedestrian to me, like much of the rest of it.  Man and flight options were okay...

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Dave S Psyllium rocks!
@Francis - Come back soon, Francis -- I hope the strike is resolved to everyones satisfaction fairly quickly.

@B 

Man, I struggled more than on many a Saturday. Lookups, autocheck - and I was still lost in the bottom section. The "misspelled" sitcom was especially cruel: I missed the lack of an E when entering the solution I found in Google and I wondered if I might be dealing with a Friday rebus ü§£. 

I still don't get the clue for CULTURAL ATTACHE - I know what that is but I can't see how may arrive at the solution from the clue.

Overall this was one of the hardest Fridays I have attempted. It is rare that I have to brute force squares with autocheck, and that is what it took in a few places today.

@B 

I'd like to see Wednesday alternate between themed and themeless.  That would provide a better home for less challenging themeless puzzles.

@Andrzej 
I don‚Äôt get the CULTURAL ATTACH√â clue, either. I solved it through crosses, and because the words fit, but not because they made any sense.

@Andrzej Aren't they embassy staff forging relationships between the two countries?

Or perhaps they're just spies.

@B 

I beat my average by 12%, but I wouldn't call this an easy puzzle.

The following answers all seemed very Friday to me:
CRAFTBEERS
TOMFOOLS
ELLIOTPAGE
ZEALOTRY
TRESLECHES
CULTURALATTACHE

@Steve 

Well, yes, I guess they do but IMO the connection between the clue and the answer is tentative at best. The clue is very vague and the answer extremely specific: I would like to know if anybody was able to solve the clue without crosses. Don't get me wrong, vague clues are only natural in end-of-the-week puzzles, but the vagueness should ultimately imply a specific answer, even if only after a long thought processes and serendipitous realizations. Here the answer relies more on crosses than the clue itself, which seems inelegant, somehow.

@Jim 

[Pricey flight options, perhaps] was terrific!  I had idoLaTRY before ZEALOTRY, so that caused a little slowdown.  PAOLa looked as good as PAOLO to me!

@Nancy J. 

I did not get the craft beer clue because I was never offered craft beer on any flight. But I fly little for environmental reasons, and when I do I don't splurge on it. I am a beer snob though so I only drink craft beers at home and at restaurants ü§£

@Nancy J. 

I already had --ALOTRY, so I tried putting in ID, and immediately said to myself, that's not how you spell "idolatry"....

I for one don't recall ever having seen the word ZEALOTRY before.  Clearly it makes sense, as I understand that it is what a zealot exhibits, and a zealot is one with a great deal of zeal for a cause.

So why do we need ZEALOTRY when we already have the simplere "zeal"?

(Is it a case of Simon says?)

@Andrzej 

In case your comment was serious, and for anyone else who doesn't get the clue:

A flight of beer (or wine or distilled spirits) is a sampler of (usually) four different products in the same category, offered in small portions and usually served in a holder designed for the purpose. You'll find this common at wineries and the like as a way to compare their products.

It's the sense of "flight" as a set, like in a flight of stairs. It has nothing to do with that which emus are incapable of.
@Andrzej The clue was referring to a different type of flight: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beer_flight I've also seen martini flights and dessert flights.

@Steve L 

I think of ZEAL as a good thing.  ZEALOTRY seems like ZEAL taken too far.

Meh, a long answer of mine did not show up. Bottom line: I've never seen a selection of alcohol called a "flight" in Poland or elsewhere on Europe. I know the thing, obviously, but not the name.








Cheeseemu.

@Andrzej 

I did need crosses to get the answer for CULTURAL ATTACHE but it felt appropriate to me: ‚Äúlong distance‚Äù for foreign (embassy) and ‚Äúrelationship‚Äù for cultural exchanges in this role. 

Flights of beer, wine, whiskey etc are a very common way to sample the various offerings at a bar here in the US. 

I take ZEAL as enthusiasm (good) and ZEALOTRY as blind fanaticism (not so good).

@Steve L 

Surprised to see you write that.  Zealotry seems like a pretty ordinary, common word to me.  Agree with @Nancy J. and others - zeal is almost always positive and zealotry almost always negative...

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Danny Sprung I got  tired of it about 60 years ago.

@Jim 

You couldn‚Äôt clue EURO as [European bread]. 

Plus, ‚ÄúFrench bread‚Äù is a ‚Äúthing‚Äù.  But what‚Äôs ‚ÄúEuropean bread‚Äù?

I agree it‚Äôs stretchy, but that‚Äôs just how Friday and Saturday puzzles are.
@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ.   Strike?  What strike?  Should we be picketing?  Am I a scab?

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ

@Chris
From what I can find on the relevant brands‚Äô websites (as well as per Wikipedia), Volkswagen is the parent company of AUDI, which is in turn the parent company of Bentley, so the clue seems to be correct (though ‚ÄúVolkswagen‚Äù would also be correct). Corporate structures can be complicated.

The Porsche family has controlling interest of VW I believe.  VW workers & the state of Bavaria also have a piece.

@Cam 

Really?! And the new clue is just bad: even if you know the series (which I don't), you can't know the answer without crosses. Crosses would probably have allowed me to solve the original clue, given what an icon of trans rights Elliot Page is. With the generic clue I just googled it because I saw no way of getting it, for its vagueness and my lack of knowledge of the series.
@LBG I was worrying about that when I had WA_K, but I'm guessing that's not what you're alluding to...
@MJ https://nytimesguild.org/tech/guild-builds/index.html

@John Carson Just to help you reach the More Replies threshold, I thought this was the easiest ever.

Looks like you didn't have much of a problem with it either.

Steve and Andrzej,

Yes, I was initially put off but it turned out to be pretty simple.  

Just a preview, I saw something today for the first time.

@Bill 

I'm a retiree who worked from home on a per session (basically freelance) basis for eight years after retirement for my previously full-time employer, a NYC public school.  

Pre-pandemic, I came into my school to do various office tasks once or twice a week, and seasonally, more often, when required.  I created the master schedule for the school, programmed the students individually, handled all the duties of the testing coordinator, such as ordering state tests and standardized tests such as the SAT and PSAT and setting up proctoring and student scheduling, and several other data-related jobs.  I worked at the pleasure of the principal, and did tasks no one else in the school was trained to do.

When the pandemic hit, there was nothing for me to do for a couple of months, and then, when schools reopened, I was given the option to work from home.  Even the teachers were working remotely at first; later, they came in and students had the option of learning remotely.

There was nothing I did that couldn't be done from home except on the day of and right before the exams, when I had to prepare the rooms and administer the exams.

Once school started up in the normal sense that fall, I was the only one who could do his job from home.  I'm not sure some of my colleagues didn't resent the fact that I was doing so, but clearly, their work could not be done from home (and neither could mine back when I was a pre-retirement full-time teacher).

(continued)

@Bill 

(Part 2)

Eventually, the principal decided I needed to come into the school a little more often.  He didn't articulate a legitimate reason; I suspect his higher-ups were generally frowning upon this practice because it may have been abused.

But I had solid reasons for not coming in.

When I was there in person, I often was sitting around waiting to be handed tasks to do.  When I worked at home, I only worked when there was something for me to do, and as a result, I could sometimes work one hour one day and five the next.  

I could work any day of the week, since it took no effort to get started; my computer was already on, even.  I didn't have to wait until there was enough work requested to make coming in worth it.

I could schedule appointments whenever I wanted, since I could work any time of day, even evenings or the middle of the night.

I didn't have to drive two hours a day just to do (and get paid for) three hours of work.  After the pandemic, everyone in the Bronx bought a car, and it took half an hour just to get to the bridge, a distance of maybe five miles.

I didn't have to waste time waiting for a clarification.  If I didn't get an answer quickly, I just got up and did other stuff, and went back to it later.

This pressure to come back to the workplace was eventually one of the factors that made me tell them I was going to stop working altogether, so they could find others to learn the various tasks I did.  

I miss the extra money, but not that much.

@Steve L 
I was running out of characters, but I wanted to add that the picket line I walked was corporeal, not digital. It was also very cold, and tiring. But I did discover that White Castle breakfast sandwiches are, in fact, quite good. (yes, I did see the photos from NYC)

Of course, folks have always "worked from home"--from the blacksmith or green-grocer who lives behind the shop, to the poet scrivening in her study. But nowadays, whenever I ask someone what they do, they typically answer using an abstract adjective followed by an abstract noun, both of Latin etymology (a language I doubt they've studied.) "Yes, but what do you actually *do*? What do you produce?" They answer using another stream of Latinate abstracts. No wonder they can perform it from home, while no doubt simultaneously attending to the crying toddler in the next room (in the end, a more worthy occupation.) And get paid more than I.

I am starting to wear the bottoms of my trousers rolled.

@Bill 

I'm really grateful I don't have to demand to work from home. 

I was never interested remote working until I was forced to by COVID but I learned how to prosper in it and now I'm glad that I can still be remote 2 days a week, or as needed. I can tell you that I get way more done in my home office than in the work office with far fewer distractions, but I also love being in the office and connecting with my colleagues. 

I also know from working at an office for 25 or so years where working remotely wasn't an option, it did not mean people were doing their work. There was a whole lot of game playing 
and shopping and whatever else people felt like doing instead of work. Sitting in an office in a building is not the same as producing good outcomes.

There are definite benefits to working from home for both employers and employees.

Of course, I could definitely tell you what I do for a living without using any abstract terms.

I hang out at the Central Park tennis courts and commune with my friends of more than 55 years because I played tennis in Central Park for all those years.  I go out to dinner with friends -- no cell phones for either of us -- and we actually have an actual conversation using real words and not textspeak. My favorite music is musicals from the Golden Age and the American Songbook; folk and folk rock played on acoustic guitars; and highly melodic non-experimental classical music.

@John Carson 

Some craft beers are ridiculously overpriced, true. I remember seeing a four-pack that was priced at $80. Some brewers are counting on the perception that a high price implies a proportional increase in quality, the kind of thing that sells $1800 sneakers (that, plus status-signaling).

But you don't have to buy the ridiculously overpriced brews, and there has been a huge increase in both quality and variety, for which I'm profoundly grateful. 

We have Jimmy Carter to thank for that. He made home brewing legal, then homebrewers revived interest in all the myriad ales, stouts, porters, pilsners, etc. that already existed at one time in the US, and then expanded on that list with a lot of innovation. And it was homebrewers that started the first American microbreweries. 

And if you still want Pabst or Budweiser or Coors, they're still available.

@Amanda I don‚Äôt use a wok for potstickers either but many woks have flat bottoms. The sides are bowl shaped.

"Flat bottom wok" is both a real thing (outside China) and an oxymoron. A flat bottom Wok has the curvature of a normal Wok, with high sloping sides and a narrow bottom. Yet, unlike a round Wok, the flat bottom Wok has a flat base, allowing it to sit steadily on any cooking top, including an induction stove. This version of the Wok was invented in 1971 by Joyce Chen, a Chinese-American immigrant. Seeing how challenging it was to use the traditional Wok in the average American home, Chen patented the flat bottom Wok. Since then, her version of the Wok has become the dominant type of Wok found outside of China. https://madeincookware.com/blogs/round-vs-flat-bottom-Wok

@Dee punctuation of all sorts is normally not part of the puzzle grid, unless it's specifically related to the theme of the puzzle. On an entry that contains an abbreviation, you wouldn't see the periods, for example. Same goes for commas in phrases that might contain them in a text. I can't think of any puzzles I've done in the NYT that contain punctuation, but there is probably one or a few over the last 30 years. The puzzle researchers can figure this one out.
